title: Lantern Pike Walking Route

images.title: Ian Balcombe / Moorland, Lantern Pike., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Moorland, Lantern Pike. The wall running across the photo marks the boundary of the National Trust property.

images.title: Ian Balcombe / On the ridge, lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: On the ridge, Lantern Pike. Footpath running along the ridge, with grouse moor either side. A killer for kids, because the monument and summit aren't at the highest point on the horizon. They are further off, only being seen once the "false summit" has been reached. Character building stuff.

images.title: Ian Balcombe / Stile on Lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stile on Lantern Pike Looking NE along the flank of Lantern Pike, towards Little Hayfield.

images.title: Ian Balcombe / Bridleway up Lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bridleway up Lantern Pike This work was done in an attempt to prevent erosion. A camber was added together with a wide stone drain to improve drainage.

images.title: Katy Walters / Toposcope, Lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Toposcope, Lantern Pike

images.title: michael ely / Pennine Bridleway, Lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cyclist on the pike. This is where the National Trail crosses the shoulder of Lantern Pike at an elevation of 340 metres. It's been a bit of a pull from the road at Birch Vale a mile to the southwest.

images.title: Katy Walters / East from Lantern Pike, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: East from Lantern Pike. Little Hayfield, Middle Moor and Kinder Scout.

images.title: Katy Walters / Lantern Pike from Middle Moor, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Lantern Pike from Middle Moor. A nice overview of the Pike and the Sett Valley.

description: This climb to Lantern Pike from Hayfield makes use of the Pennine Bridleway. It's a circular walk which starts in the village of Hayfield and takes you along the Sett Valley Trail to Birch Vale Reservoir. Here you turn north and climb to the 373 metres (1,224 ft) summit of the hill. At the summit you can take in some wonderful views of the surrounding Peak District hills and countryside. The walk then descends to the pretty hamlet of Little Hayfield before crossing Middle Moor and following the Snake Path back to Hayfield. If you would like to continue your walking in the area then a walk to Kinder Scout and Kinder Reservoir is a great option.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: After your walk we recommend heading to the appropriately named Lantern Pike Inn in Hayfield. The interesting old pub dates from 1792, and has a very good menu. There's also a nice outdoor seating area where you can relax outside and enjoy views of the surrounding hills. You can find the pub in the village on 45 Glossop Rd, Little Hayfield with postcode SK222NG for your sat navs. The pub also does accommodation so you can stay over here if you need to.

display_address: 40, Station Road, Hayfield, Little Hayfield, High Peak, Derbyshire, East Midlands, England, SK22 2ES, United Kingdom
